awd_titl_txt: Excellence in Research: Crosstalk between the STK4/Hippo and NF-Kappa B pathway in mammalian cells
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to understand how molecular signals inside the cell are used to control cell size and growth, cell migration, and cell survival under changing environmental conditions. Using mammalian cells grown in culture, undergraduate and graduate students from an undergraduate institution that serves students from disproportionately underrepresented African-American communities will use a range of biochemical, molecular biology, genetics, and genomics approaches to determine how components from different signaling pathways communicate to coordinate cell growth. This project will provide undergraduate and graduate students with  training and educational opportunities in biological sciences, allowing them to further pursue career goals in academia or in life sciences industries. Additionally, incorporation of research findings from this project into the classroom curriculum will further enhance their quality of education and research in life sciences, helping to reduce disparities in STEM employment by broadening participation in the Nation's STEM research workforce.

This project will investigate the mechanism of the interaction between the YAP/TEAD protein, a key nuclear effector of the STK4/Hippo pathway, and RELA, a component of the NF-Kappa B (NFκB) transcription factors.  The aims of this project are (a) to define the signaling mechanism that regulates YAP/TEAD and RELA interactions, (b) to determine the mechanism by which YAP/TEAD and RELA proteins physically interact in the cell, and (c) to demonstrate whether YAP/TEAD regulates the RELA-DNA interaction and the RELA-dependent gene transcription and cellular function. The techniques to be utilized in this project include high-throughput RNA or DNA sequencing, CRISPR/Cas9-aided genome editing, chromatin-immunoprecipitation and other molecular assays, and bioinformatics data analysis. The outcomes of this research include a comprehensive dissection of  the mechanism of crosstalk between the STK4/Hippo and NFκB signaling in mammalian cells.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this Excellence in Research Award is to investigate the biochemical and functional interactions between the Hippo and NF-Kappa B pathways in cell models, particularly in response to cytokines and steroid hormone androgens. These pathways are crucial for regulating key cellular processes including proliferation, cell contact, motility, survival, differentiation, as well as developmental and immunological processes, and disease biology such as cancer, diabetes, and aging. The research supported by this award utilized biochemistry, cell, and molecular biology techniques, including proteomics, transcriptomics, and computational data analysis, to accomplish the research goal.

Key findings reveal that cytokines and androgens regulate YAP1 nuclear abundance and its protein-protein interaction dynamics, likely by inhibiting the Hippo pathway, a key suppressor of YAP1 activity. This study also identifies YAP1 as a key regulator of NF-Kappa B interaction dynamics and transcriptional activity, downstream of the Hippo pathway. Additionally, the study uncovers overlapping DNA binding sites for TEAD and NF-Kappa B transcription factors, highlighting their cooperation and critical roles in gene regulation. These insights enhance our understanding of cellular adaptation and gene expression, providing a foundation for future research with implications for disease processes and potential therapeutic strategies. Consequently, this study will likely advance broad scientific disciplines including cell and developmental biology, immunology, and cancer biology.

This Excellence in Research Award has contributed to the publication of three research articles in high-impact, peer-reviewed journals: Journal of Biological Sciences, Scientific Reports, and iScience. Additionally, this award has supported three manuscripts, with two currently under revision and one in preparation. The award also facilitated the presentation of eight scientific abstracts at prestigious conferences such as the American Society of Cell Biology (ASCB) and the American Society of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (ASBMB). Besides, this award led to the development of two federally funded research proposals. These achievements will strengthen the research infrastructure at Clark Atlanta University.

Moreover, the award provided valuable research experience for ten undergraduate students from historically black colleges and universities through stipends and research support. It also offered training opportunities for four PhD and one MS graduate students. Of these, three PhD students have graduated: two are now postdoctoral fellows at prestigious universities, and one is an assistant professor at a U.S. college. Additionally, the award supported the career development of a postdoctoral research associate, who is currently a staff scientist at a U.S. biotechnology company. These achievements will continue to foster impactful training and research opportunities for future scholars from underrepresented communities.

Furthermore, the project enabled the principal investigator, a postdoctoral fellow, and seven students to attend and present research at local, national, and international scientific conferences, including the ASCB and ASBMB annual meetings. This positively impacted their professional development in the life sciences disciplines. Feedback from students indicated that integrating research findings into graduate and undergraduate curricula positively impacted student learning and success in the subject, motivating them to pursue laboratory research to further their careers in the life sciences field. Ultimately, this Excellence in Research Award had a positive impact in reducing disparities in STEM employment across the United States, thereby enhancing the lives of individuals from underrepresented and economically diverse backgrounds in the long term.

In summary, the Excellence in Research Award shed lights on how cytokines and androgens regulate YAP1 and NF-Kappa B activities in human cells. This research advances understanding of cellular adaptation and gene expression under changing environmental conditions, providing a foundation for future research with implications for disease processes. The award resulted in three published research articles, eight conference presentations, and two new federally-funded research proposals, strengthening the education and research infrastructure. This award also provided research experience for ten undergraduates and training for five graduate students, enhancing career opportunities, and reducing STEM disparities in the US.


Last Modified: 12/22/2024
Modified by: Bekir Cinar

Image
  • Cytokines and androgens work together to enhance the protein-protein interaction between YAP1 and RELA within the cell. (A) The interaction of YAP1 with RELA, as demonstrated by a proximity ligation assay. (B, C) The formation of protein complexes between RELA and TEAD proteins is mediate
